 Random is random. Whether you're guessing for just 1 answer or 100, the odds of you getting the right one are only 1 in 4, no matter which one you choose. Think of it this way. If you were only guess for 1 answer, you wouldn't think that guessing A would give you a better chance than any other guess, right? Well, the questions have no memory, and they don't know what the other answers were. Once you've guessed at that first one (and one guess was as good as any other) than whatever you guessed there and whatever the correct answer was will have no bearing on the next question. Any guess will be just as good there. And so on for the rest of the questions. If you aren't convinced than try this. Take two decks of cards, shuffle them both, then deal them out one card at a time from each deck. If you layed them out, you would have two columns of 52 cards. Count how many times the suits match between pairs of cards from the opposing decks. It'll be about 13. Maybe more, maybe less, but if you did it over and over it would average out to exactly 13. Give it a try.

It depends on whether the questions have had the answers randomised or arranged by hand. Chances are, if it is the latter, you will get 25% right by putting all the marks down one column. The former means you are likely to get widely varying results, as humans tend to underestimate the chances of getting long strings of results the same. But basically it doesn't really make any difference.

 Of course, filling the answers straight down is quicker than bouncing around. Your chances of getting any right aren't better, but it may save you a few seconds and let you guess on a couple more. That may be what your teachers were thinking.

I'm talking about random events here. It's pretty easy to see that if you guess a certain value - A - that there is 1 way to be right (A is correct) and 3 ways to be wrong (B, C, or D is correct). But if you guess your value at random, then you could choose any of 4 values, each of which could be matched only 1 way and be wrong 3 ways, giving a total of 4 ways to be right but 12 ways to be wrong. 
 
 With a difference of only 2 in the first case (3 ways to be wrong - 1 way to be right), but a difference of 8 in the second (12 ways to be wrong - 4 ways to be right), psychologically, it seems that your chances of being right instead of being wrong is much better in the first case than the second. Thus, it appears that sticking with a certain value is better. Besides, the first case is easy to calculate mentally but the second takes more effort, thereby things get lost in the fog: so you have a clear picture of the first but a foggy picture of the second, making the first again appear, psychologically, to be preferred.
 
 However, the math for the second case takes only a little extra thought. And, more importantly, it is not the difference that is important but rather the ratio: in both cases, it's 1/4. In the first, there is 1 way out of 4 to be right: that is 1/4. In the second, there are four ways to be right and 12 ways to be wrong, for a total of 4 ways out of 16 to be right: 4/16 = 1/4. 
 
 Psychologically, the first might appear better, but mathematically it's a tie.
